thread.title_full: RCG says 'insatiable appetite' for sneakers driving sales

title: RCG says 'insatiable appetite' for sneakers driving sales
text:
RCG chief executive Hilton Brett expects earnings to more than double this year after his $203 mln acquisition of Accent Group.
 Footwear retailer RCG says an "insatiable appetite" for sneakers will drive double-digit sales and 150-per cent plus earnings growth this year as it steps into new categories after the $203 million acquisition of Accent Group.
RCG expects earnings before interest tax depreciation and amortisation to reach $55 million to $57 million in 2016 – more than double underlying EBITDA of $21.8 million in 2015 – fuelled by strong sales of existing brands such as Sperry and Saucony and new brands including Vans, Dr Martens and Skechers.
"If you look around the world all the young people are wearing on their feet is sneakers – there's an insatiable appetite to satisfy them," RCG chairman Ivan Hammerschlag told investors on Thursday.
RCG plans to tap this demand after completing the acquisiton of Accent Group, which sells licensed footwear brands such as Vans, Skechers and Dr Martens and owns the Platypus Shoes chain.
Advertisement The deal doubled RCG's store footprint to 300, added new brands to its portfolio and boosted annual sales to almost $500 million, making it the largest footwear retailer in Australia and New Zealand.
RCG had control of Accent for only five weeks but in that time Accent's same-store sales soared 31 per cent after rising 29 per cent to $215 million in the 12 months ending April.
The strong gains continued into 2016. Accent's same-store sales rose 37 per cent in the first seven weeks, with Skechers one of the standouts.
"The ongoing performance of the Accent business is unprecedented in the current retail climate," said RCG chief executive HiIton Brett, "with 30 per cent like for like growth over the last 12 months and double-digit like-for-like growth in each of the two years before that."
"There's no question the active lifestyle space and athleisure space is experiencing strong growth," he said.
RCG's Brands business also did well, with strong demand for Sperry Topsiders, Saucony sports shoes and sneakers and CAT boots offsetting weak demand for Merrell's lifestyle range. Sales rose 36 per cent, underpinning a 24 per cent increase in earnings.
This offset lacklustre growth in RCG's core The Athletes Foot business, where sales rose only 2.5 per cent and earnings by 1.1 per cent, triggering a strategic review that could lead to new store formats.
Including Accent, RCG's underlying net profit rose 16 per cent to $13.7 million, falling slightly short of market forecasts around $14.4 million.
One-off costs associated with the deal, which was funded through a $25 million placement to institutional investors, a $28 million unsecured vendor note and $50 million of bank debt, dragged statutory net profit down 11.7 per cent to $10.3 million.
RCG maintained its final dividend at 2.5¢, preserving its cash to fund new stores and refurbishments. Accent plans to open 20 stores in 2016, including 12 before the end of September.
RCG shares, which have risen 53 per cent since March, shed 3¢ to $1.12.
